content: * *Sir Eric Newton Griffith-Jones** [KBE](/wiki/Order_of_the_British_Empire) [CMG](/wiki/Order_of_St_Michael_and_St_George) [QC](/wiki/Queen%27s_Counsel) (1 November 1913 – 13 February 1979) was a British lawyer and administrator who served as [Attorney General of Kenya](/wiki/Attorney_General_of_Kenya) between 1955 and 1961. ## Early life Griffith-Jones was born in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore) in 1913 to Oswald Phillips Griffith-Jones and his wife Edith. His paternal aunt was [Anne Griffith-Jones](/wiki/Anne_Griffith-Jones). He was educated at [Cheltenham College](/wiki/Cheltenham_College) and was [called to the bar](/wiki/Call_to_the_bar) at [Gray's Inn](/wiki/Gray%27s_Inn) in 1934. ## Career On completing his studies, he joined the [Colonial Legal Service](/wiki/Colonial_Service) and in 1935 began his career as a solicitor and advocate in [Straits Settlements](/wiki/Straits_Settlements) and [Johor](/wiki/Johor). In 1939 he became [Crown Counsel](/wiki/Crown_Counsel) in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore). He saw active military service during the [Second World War](/wiki/Second_World_War) and was a prisoner of war between 1942 and 1945. After the war, he resumed his legal career as a Crown Counsel in the [Malayan Union](/wiki/Malayan_Union). In the early 1950s, he moved to [Kenya](/wiki/Kenya) and was made [Queen's Counsel](/wiki/Queen%27s_Counsel) in 1954. The following year, he was appointed Attorney-General and Minister for Legal Affairs. He served as [Acting Governor](/wiki/List_of_colonial_governors_and_administrators_of_Kenya) in 1962–63. In 1963 he succeeded Sir John Hay as head of [Guthrie](/wiki/Guthrie_(company)) and oversaw a restructuring of the group. He spent his later years on the board of several companies. ## Death He died on 13 February 1979, at 65.
